title: Almondell and Calderwood Country Park Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: M J Richardson / Almondell & Country Park Visitor Centre
images.caption: Almondell & Country Park Visitor Centre From the garden, with three historic stones from Kirhill House incorporated in the wall to the left.

images.title: M J Richardson / Almondell and Calder Wood Country Park
images.caption: The feeder for the Union Canal crossing the R. Almond just downsteam from the weir where the feed is taken from the river. The National Cycleway Network path no. 75 crosses the aqueduct. The water starts its journey at Cobbinshaw Reservoir and reaches the Almond via the Murieston and Linhouse Waters. It enters the canal at the viaduct which crosses the Almond near Clifton Hall

images.title: Jim Smillie / Deciduous woodland Almondell
images.caption: Deciduous woodland Almondell. Grass on the flat land, woodland on the steep slope

images.title: M J Richardson / The River Almond in Almondell & Calderwood Country Park
images.caption: The River Almond in the park. Looking upstream, through the Naysmith Bridge.

images.title: Chris Heaton / Daffodils, Almondell & Calder Wood Country Park
images.caption: Daffodils in the park in April 2008. Floral display near the southern entrance of the Country Park near East Calder.

images.title: M J Richardson / The Kirkhill Pillar in Almondell
images.caption: The Kirkhill Pillar. The original pillar that inspired the Kirkhill Pillar Project. Now located at the Almondell & Calderwood Visitor Centre.

description: Explore 220 acres of country park near Broxburn on this easy cycle or walk. In the park you will find peaceful woodland and a lovely waterside trail running along the River Almond. Almondell is a haven for wildlife - look out for Roe deer, fox, heron, otters and woodpeckers as you make your way through the park. Also of interest is the excellent Visitor Centre with displays, a gallery, information and a conservatory with a cafe. If you would like to continue your outing you could head north to the Union Canal. You could follow the towpath east into Edinburgh on foot or bike.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: There is a cafe/coffee stand near the visitor centre and a number of picnic tables at the site too.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The parkland and woodland are ideal for dog walking so you're bound to pass other owners with their pets on your visit.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: Head a few miles south west of the park and you can visit Cobbinshaw Reservoir where there are some nice waterside trails to try. Eliburn Reservoir can also be found nearby on the western side of Livingston. To the south there's Harperrig Reservoir. Here you'll find some interesting wildlife including various wildfowl and the Eurasian otter. The site also includes views of the Water of Leith and the 15th century Cairns Castle ruins. At the eastern end of the lake you can pick up the long distance Cross Borders Drove Road. It runs south through the Pentland Hills to West Linton, Peebles, Traquair and then on to Hawick via the Yarrow Valley. For cyclists Sustrans National Cycle Route 75 passes through the park. This signed route takes you from Edinburgh to Glasgow and then to Portavadie on the shores of Loch Fyne on the west coast of the Cowal peninsula in Argyll and Bute.

display_address: Almondell Country Park - South Car Park, Main Street, Calderwood, East Calder, West Lothian, Alba / Scotland, EH53 0ES, United Kingdom
